docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: In ''Health Care Problem? Check the American Psyche'' (Economic View, Dec. 31), Anna Bernasek said that most Americans don't believe that an effective single-payer health care system is possible. I think that most Americans have encountered some aspect of the modern medical culture -- where everything can be based on price, and where patients are marketing targets -- and they don't like it.
docs.abstract: Letter from Margaret Eiszner about December 31 Economic View column proposes debate for single-payer health care system (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: For each person whose life has been eased by money provided by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, there is a donor who has been moved to make a difference. For some, donating to the Neediest Cases is part of a tradition of giving. More and more often, that tradition is carried out online. ''Younger people are much more likely to make gifts online. So it's likely that an ever-increasing proportion of donors, children of the digital generation, feel the same compassion that their elders have demonstrated over the 95-year life of the Neediest Cases campaigns,'' said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation. ''Virtually and actually, we're grateful.''
